Award.AwardTitle: Effects Of Traditional Cradling Practices On Infants' Physical, Motor, And Social Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Prominent theories of infant development have been built on the premise that freedom to move is essential (e.g., Gibson, 1988), and that restricted movement is harmful for development. Since it is ethically unacceptable for researchers to test effects of restricted movement by intentionally restraining infants, many studies have taken advantage of 'natural experiments' provided by cases of children reared in impoverished conditions, such as children in Romanian orphanages who were left in their cribs most of the time (e.g., Nelson, Fox, & Zeanah, 2014). However, in these situations, children were also deprived of social interaction with caregivers, which makes separating the effects of restricted movement versus other types of deprivation difficult.
This work capitalizes on a rare chance to study effects of restricted movement on infant development by examining the use of a 'gahvora' cradle in Tajikistan in Central Asia where restriction of infant movement is common, but infants receive plenty of social interaction and affection. Dr. Karasik, her collaborators, Drs. Adolph and Tamis-LeMonda, and their international research team will investigate the physical, motor, and social development of Tajik infants based on the duration and degree of restriction they experience during the first two years of life. This work also provides insights into whether and how development of motor skills influences development in other domains such as interactions with objects and people.
This study addresses issues that are core to developmental psychology, including questions about cross-cultural consistency in children's development and the effects of context on early experiences and emerging skills. Data will be shared with the broader scientific community through the Databrary.org video data-sharing library. This project will engage undergraduate students and researchers in the U.S. and abroad by offering training in research methods and developmental science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to study effects of restricted movement on infant development. Since it is ethically unacceptable to test effects of restricted movement experimentally, this project capitalized on a rare chance to study a traditional childrearing practice in Central Asia in which infants’ limbs are restricted in a “gahvora” cradle (Figure 1A). Data were collected in Tajikistan where we have partnered with UNICEF and Save the Children International (SCI). Three specific aims guided this project. We aimed to: (1) solidify partnerships with UNICEF, SCI, and local medical facilities for recruiting families; (2) develop and refine time- diary and video recording methods to document use of the gahvora and assess variability around the practice; and (3) collect video data and develop measures of infant physical development, motor skills, object-directed behavior, and social interactions to examine effects of cradling on infant development across these domains. These goals were accomplished in two studies. In Study 1, we assessed the variability in the practice by using time-diary and video recording methods. We reported on daily use of the cradle, extent of restriction in the cradle, and changes in the practice over development. In Study 2, we examined the effects of cradling on infants’ physical development, motor development, and object and social engagement by assessing infants in standard tests and during spontaneous activity video recorded in families’ homes. During this report period (2/15/16 to 8/31/16) we completed the final steps of the one-year project: We presented findings at the International Congress on Infant Studies; participated in a meeting of researchers studing cross-cultual issues in Vancouver; we travelled to Tajikistan to rather equipment and close out the project and meet with UNICEF to present findings and discuss future collaborations.These activities globalized developmental research and bridged the gap between scientific research and international agencies interested in child development. This project offered unique training opportunities for undergraduate, masters, and post-doctoral students in the U.S. and Tajikistan. We have established new collaborations with organizations in Tajikistan interested in developmental research to develop next questions.
